channel.title: Comments on: Show message for SSRS reports that do not return data
channel.description: A Technical Community for IT Professionals

item.title: By: Mielaya
item.dc:creator: Mielaya
item.description: As Dan mentioned, there is a table property <b>NoRows</b> under the <b>Data Category</b> in the <b>Properties Window</b>. It will display any message you put into the expression when there are no rows returned by the dataset. It is a much easier way of doing what has been described. I know this works in 2005, not sure about 2008 :-)<br /> Thanks for the article.
item.content:encoded:
As Dan mentioned, there is a table property NoRows under the Data Category in the Properties Window. It will display any message you put into the expression when there are no rows returned by the dataset. It is a much easier way of doing what has been described. I know this works in 2005, not sure about 2008 ðŸ™‚
Thanks for the article.

item.title: By: Hemant Rathi
item.dc:creator: Hemant Rathi
item.description: Its really very good Idea. Thanks you have saved my at least 1 hour. Thanks
item.content:encoded: Its really very good Idea. Thanks you have saved my at least 1 hour. Thanks

item.title: By: MIKE ZINGG
item.dc:creator: MIKE ZINGG
item.description: This is a good way to display an error message. I had previously been displaying an error message in a textox with a rectangle, and conditionally hiding it. The problem with that, even hiding the rectangle/texbox, is that the report still accounts for that space, even though the rectangle and textbox are not visible, causing your table to start being display deeper in the page. Thanks.
item.content:encoded: This is a good way to display an error message. I had previously been displaying an error message in a textox with a rectangle, and conditionally hiding it. The problem with that, even hiding the rectangle/texbox, is that the report still accounts for that space, even though the rectangle and textbox are not visible, causing your table to start being display deeper in the page. Thanks.

item.title: By: Dan
item.dc:creator: Dan
item.description: you can also set tht NoRowsMessage on the table properties.
item.content:encoded: you can also set tht NoRowsMessage on the table properties.

item.title: By: riverguy
item.dc:creator: riverguy
item.description: One thing I noticed is that the method to hide the textbox works in the Visual Studio preview pane, but the textbox shows regardless once deployed to the report server. This is a report developed in Visual Studio 2005 deployed to SSRS 2008. The hide method applied to the textbox works great, however.
item.content:encoded: One thing I noticed is that the method to hide the textbox works in the Visual Studio preview pane, but the textbox shows regardless once deployed to the report server. This is a report developed in Visual Studio 2005 deployed to SSRS 2008. The hide method applied to the textbox works great, however.

item.title: By: riverguy
item.dc:creator: riverguy
item.description: That's a pretty good idea. I think I might start implementing that. Actually, this gives me another idea: for certain reports which usually include a date range context and are sourced from a data warehouse (therefore being less up to date than the source system), I might include a "Data current as of MM/DD/YYY" snippet in addition to the No data returned text.
item.content:encoded: That’s a pretty good idea. I think I might start implementing that. Actually, this gives me another idea: for certain reports which usually include a date range context and are sourced from a data warehouse (therefore being less up to date than the source system), I might include a “Data current as of MM/DD/YYY” snippet in addition to the No data returned text.
